reviewText: Highly recommended! Should have won many Oscars--especially BEST PICTURE. Thought-provoking. Entertaining. Spell-binding. Well worth owning--should be in any true lover of cinema's film collection. Roger Ebert (RIP) was right!
summary: One of the best of all time!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I came late to this party.  It's a shame, too.  I wish I had seen it on a big screen.  This is a terrific film.  But it isn't for everyone.  You will need to be well rested, (it's nearly 3 hours long) and you will need to bring a few things with you.  One is your brain.  Yes, Virginia, you will have to think to comprehend this movie.  You will need to pay attention, listen carefully and think.As one reviewer suggested, bring a Buddhist with you to explain some of the metaphysical aspects of the film.  You don't have to be a Buddhist to get it, but you should be familiar with the ideas reincarnation and karma.  That said, the film is not austere in any sense of the word.  It is fast-paced, and by turns, moving, thrilling and mesmerizing.Watching for the principal actors in each time-frame is entertaining in a "Where's Waldo?" kind of way.  The effects are sumptuous, the story is meaty, and the transitions are deft. "What's not to like?" you may ask.  It's simple.  If you want a movie laid out in one or two straight plot-lines, cookie-cutter characters, some jiggling boobs, and a few sight-gags and pratfalls thrown in for good measure, you had better go dig out an old "Dukes of Hazzard" VHS tape and crack open a Bud.  You will be out of your depth with "Cloud Atlas."
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I suspect this is one of those films that most people will fall into a love it or hate it camp.  It is long (just short of 3 hours), complicated and controversial.  Actors Tom Hanks, Jim Broadbent, Halle Berry, Jim Sturgess, Ben Whishaw and Hugh Grant play half a dozen roles and another handful of actors have 3 or more characters.  Unless you know ahead of time, you will have a hard time identifying some of the actors.  That certainly is part of the fun.It is nearly impossible to try to describe a plot or a story, so let me just say that there is a connection between the characters that strongly suggest a minimum of déjà vu and the probability of reincarnation.  The six stories cover a period from 1849 to 2349 and somehow the directors and co-writers (Lana and sibling Andy Wachowski along with Tom Tykwer) and especially editor Alexander Berner, make the transition between the segments amazingly seamless.  It will take me another viewing or two to come close to making all the links but suffice it to say, it's all there.What is interesting is that each actor's character does not necessarily have the same values or personality in another segment.  There is an evolution of sorts that is transpiring.  In that the individual stories cover half a millennium, it is remarkable that each segment is handled so beautifully when it comes to the technical aspects of the production.  In any one scene we see a sailing ship crossing an ocean transition to a 1970's reporter investigating a potential nuclear cover-up and on to a futuristic battle for human survival.  The film is funny at times, erotic on occasion and full of big screen wonder.  I need to see it again.
summary: 4 1/2 stars for one of the best movies of 2012
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I was really looking forward to this movie, but I didn't go to the theater. I thought there would be this amazing metaphysical thread to follow but instead it was a mish-mush of harshly edited cuts from one story to the another. Despite the obvious connections made, it lacked any feeling about it. And that ...be the true true!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I saw this on the big screen and walked out in awe. I liked watching it on DVD and plan to do so again. I haven't yet watched the commentary version, but I'm looking forward to it.Important "spoiler" alert: The movie and the book are not the same. They cannot be. But the movie is faithful to the "intent" or main idea of the novel, with some important exceptions, i.e., the ending is more "American" than the novel.
summary: Needs to be watched more than once
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: While I found the idea excellent, and I'm sure lots of people have thought about this one. I have. It didn't really have a point except that we are different in each lifetime, and possibly connected to the same people over and over again. I kept waiting for something, but it never happened.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This film is probably one of the best I have ever seen. By far, the best film of 2012. I really hope this movie gets nominated and takes home a couple oscars because it definitely deserves them. I mean the plot, characters, screenplay, cinematography, special effects, costumes, make up and just the plain story line are done and acted out so perfectly! I love this film and will definitely purchase it on blu-ray!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Great performance (and make-up) by a handful of stars playing all the roles.  The movie's message of redemption was moving.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This film does not spoon feed any easy conclusions about human struggles.  Having each actor play multiple roles is not about reincarnation but rather how much we are a product of environment.  Yes it's a very long 3 hours.  Watch half and then sleep on it.  My favorite novel is "Point Counterpoint" so I enjoy a "God like" perspective of peripherally connected characters forced to examine their lives.  Of course some will interest you more than others.  Despite the occasionally awkward script, Jim Broadbent and the cinematographers deserved oscars.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I like the idea of a film that not only can be enjoyed more than one time, but gives more enjoyment from multiple viewings. Cloud Atlas is such a film. It requires multiple viewings due to it's depth and complexity. It's good science fiction from the old school, when a requirement of memorable science fiction was that it provoke a sense of wonder. Cloud Atlas does that. It does suffer a little here and there because of some political correctness, but it's easily ignored. All in all it's a good science fiction film for your library. High production value, great acting, and incredibly beautiful cinematography make it a winner.
summary: A modern science fiction movie, designed to be viewed more than once.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: As always Tom Hanks gives us a tear churker . Theirs more then one love story . Prepare yourself with napkins by your side .
summary: Great movie to watch on a rainy day
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This network of lives and their events is woven carefully and intelligently through separate planes of different times.  A job well done!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I struggled to follow the story-line, and as I sit here trying to summarize, I still can't tell you what was "going on" in this film. Visually stunning, VERY well acted (especially Tom Hanks).But the average movie-watcher (me) spends too much time trying to make sense of it all to really enjoy it.Perhaps if you went back and watched "Cloud Atlas" a few more times it would start to connect. I won't.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Very interesting movie, sometimes hard to keep track of things, fun to figure out the characters (Tom Hanks doesn't even look like himself in some time frames!), great acting.

reviewText: I usually love any movie Tom Hanks is in. This one was not what I expected. It's a long drawn out story that could have been told in the first five minutes. I found my mind wandering at time because of boredom and about 45 minutes in...I just wanted it to be OVER already.

reviewText: Not a great movie, but very thought provoking. This is one of the few movies that I like better than the book (which is really saying something considering how great the book is). The layered story structure makes it a lot of fun to rewatch.

reviewText: Excellent movie all the way through. Great storyline and wonderful actors. I would reccommend anyone over 13 that has 3hrs sit down, relax and enjoy this movie.

reviewText: this movie is a must see, full of wonderful symbolism and great imagery. all and all a great experience. love it
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The whole movie consists of brief, incoherent clips of the same actors, many of them with badly applied plaster on their faces, playing different characters on different times and places, who are supposedly related to each other in some incomprehensible way. One ends up suspecting that this is also incomprehensible to the directors and scriptwriters, hence their inability to explain it.Too many of the clips are grotesque and ridiculous. Some of them clearly intend to be humorous, such as for example some extended and unbearable scenes of a group of elderly people, but they are just boring and badly made. It is just amazing to see how  very talented actors like Jim Broadbent and Hugo Weaving can be utterly wasted in this clumsy film.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: One night when I could not get to sleep (again) I decided to rent this. I enjoyed the story,the acting, Tom hanks is one of my favorite actors. I usually don't care for Halle Berry, but she was ok in this one. I would watch it again

reviewText: Well done movie, great actors, deep concept, make you think and not just for entertainment!  If you like a smart movies, the ones that make you see it over and over again and still find every time something new, you should get this one!

reviewText: I took a chance and I want my 3 hours back.  It's one of those movies you think it's gotta get better because Tom Hanks is in it, but nope.  I don't get this movie as too many stories intertwine in such a way that you want to go home.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cloud AtlasI don't really think there's a spoiler but I didn't want to get popped if I accidentally understood any part of this movie and there-by said something “spoiling” about it.If you were looking at reviews of this movie and you set the 'search' to “hated it” on IMDB you'd get a good dose of what I felt like most the time with the movie.  I am, however, giving it 3 stars assuming that rating is “it's ok” vs. 2, “I didn't like it”.  Because, despite my complaints, which are multitude, I didn't feel like it was a total waste of my time.I obtained this movie to watch based on “Tom Hanks” and nothing else. That won't be happening again. I didn't watch it for ages though.  Seeing it sitting around yesterday (12-16-13) I looked at the IMDB blurb and thought, “This might be interesting.”  I didn't read any reviews.I had the idea this was a time travel movie.  See Tom Hanks old, see Tom Hanks much younger in scenes close together... I don't think that assumption was a leap.  But that really isn't what's going on in this movie.  While trying to think what it is like, I remember that as a child my mother would buy me connect the dot books.  Connect the dots correctly....  Elephant!  Hooray!This movie has dots galore. I wasn't connecting the dots, or if I was connecting the dots it was turning out to be a dream-catcher, not a movie. I did get that it was a series or parallel of stories and I was able to “care” about several of the stories as they hopped and skipped about, but it wasn't going to mold itself into the science fiction time travel movie I had been suspected in the beginning.Maybe if I watched it a few times or if it had closed captions I would have liked it more.  I'm still pretty sure it was like movies that start in the middle, go to the end, and end with the beginning. But this movie was juggling several stories at once while doing that jumble the plot thing.  I think.  Probably why some people raved about the movie as genius.  I'll be calling BS on that one.There was one part where I had a “moment” that I really enjoyed.  Others probably not.  It was where one of Hank's “native” characters was talking gibberish to an anthropologist (I think).  I think that because the “advanced” person slipped in and out of talking “normal” and talking gibberish when addressing Hank's character.  What sort of surprised me is I cogged the gibberish.  True, true.I won't go so far as to say, “Don't waste your time.”  I've read some reviews now and some folks really like it.  I'm guessing if you like to put jigsaw puzzles together while knitting, this movie would add pleasantly to your entertainment time.  Or not.  Your mileage may vary. I didn't have the added extra, or bonus version.
summary: Cogged that part, true, true.  But only that...
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Really thought it was not Tom Hanks at his best.....but I guess you have to take good with the Great movies he made....
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The movie is entertaining and it is well made. However, the story makes absolutely no sense. I am sure there is a point to the story, but I guess I was not smart enough to figure it out.

Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I loved this movie, and it has stuck with me since I watched it. The only negative was how quickly some of the dialogue (in unique dialect) was spoken.  The story was very complex, with times being mixed up, past., present, future all intermingled.  I will need to see it at least once more, may more! The story is haunting.  What future are we headed for?
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: And in the endThe love you takeIs equal to the love you make......4 main characters go round and round.......in time.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Too many issues with this film to mention here. It tries too hard to be an epic film, yet falls far short of that milestone. There is a good reason editors do not like flashbacks, flash forwards and all those jumpy narrative techniques- handled badly it undermines the narrative. Not to mention the makers should have taken a cue from the last 3 Star Wars movies and stayed away from the made up dialect. in this case it was incomprehensible. Or as Yoda would say, "Understand you I cannot, said I."
summary: Too disjointed a narrative for me
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This movie is beyond bad, nothing good to say about it whatsoever, wish I could get my rental money back !!!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I viewed this film before reading the novel or knowing anything about the story, and fell in love with it. I kept an open mind and had no expectations, and wound up loving the movie. After watching, I immediately ordered the book and devoured it, simply because I couldn't get enough of these characters or the unique way in which this tale is crafted. The film is not without faults, however it is one I plan to watch many more times as it took me on a journey that I will not easily tire of. If you're having a night in and want to watch a movie that will make you think and feel abundantly, I highly recommend Cloud Atlas.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The frequent jumping from time and place to other times and places/characters was very confusing but it was an enjoyable film never-the-less. Suggest watching the extras to get a feel on how and why the time/place/person jumps take place in the film and the whole thing makes logical sense from that point on. Third time through watching far more enjoyable than the first.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I will make this short and brief. This was a very deep movie on so many levels. Six stories woven into this complex but somewhat comprehensive design. Be ready to sit and really watch this movie. It is a lot to take in and I can understand if some people didn't like it. The movie pulls you in and then makes you work to understand what it is happening. Even Tom Hanks stated he read the script and knew he had to do it but didn't understand what the hec he would be doing. It took a lot of effort for the actors to absorb not only one role but 6! Cloud Atlas is about boundaries, connection, morality, and a little love. It is about 3 hours at least almost. By near the end of the movie I was crying, understanding this movie on such a deeper level that I couldn't even explain it to you. Or try. It got to my core and I took it personally in such a powerful way. You will love it or hate it. I thought it was profound. Not as ingenious as Inception, but definitely an exploration of film that I never saw before.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This movie is about the reverberations of human actions and consequences spreading out through time, and at a very deep level of abstraction, as revealed through a collection of vivid concrete stories. But don't believe any interpretation/explanations you read--even this, believe only what the movie reveals to you.  Still, from my own experience I have to believe many people will find this move deeply rewarding for diverse reasons.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: We saw this movie in theaters and loved it.  I love it more than the book.I gave the dvd copy to my mom, she was engrossed.  The disk played well.My husband and I watched the Blu-ray copy today.  The sound did not play properly at first.Hubby dug into the settings in the menu of the disk and discovered that the English version of this on the Blu-ray was set up only as Dolby 5.1 Surround Sound.The French and Spanish versions on the disk offered Dolby 5.1 Surround Sound OR Stereo, so when we chose Stereo French it played and sounded great!He was able to use the menu settings on our Blu-ray player to tell that machine to down-mix the Dolby 5.1 input to play properly through our speakers.  I'm lucky I have a tech-savy, patient guy to figure this out, because I would have been frustrated and baffled.Anyways, once he figured out the sound work-around, all was well.  I do recommend this movie very very highly!  You will be amazed when you watch the credits and see how the same actors played so many roles with outstanding makeup, wig, and costume variations.  It's just incredible.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: When will SciFi writers finally put down the Time Travel / Dimensional Jump storylines for awhile?I’m a Chemist… but this writing approach appears to be the greatest cop-out, instead of having to tell a logical, progressive, practical tale.Your girlfriend will fall asleep.You’ll wonder why you stayed awake….
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewerName: Pamela "I love technology, reading, music, an...
reviewText: I REALLY wanted to love this movie.  I love the actors; I love the premise of reincarnation.  But I watch movies to be entertained, not to sit for weeks and ponder about the meaning of life.  So for that reason, I didn't enjoy this movie.  Perhaps it is one of those movies, where if I had read the book I could have filled in the gaps.  However, since I haven't read the book, it really didn't gel for me.  I will consider reading the book and then watch it again, and perhaps then I will be enlightened like the other reviewers.
summary: Perhaps I need to read the book
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I had heard nothing but negative about this movie. How confusing it was, that the graphics and effects were good but not enough to carry to the movie and a total WOW mind blower kind movie.Well, the first two are wrong, but the last is correct. Like butterfly effect, this movie takes you out of the normal 'think' and into an alternative think. Once you understand what you are watching and the progression of each character, you will most certainly enjoy the movie.Pamela OCitrus Heights Ca
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Blu Ray version:  Fans of Tom Hanks & Halle Berry will most likely enjoy this film - although the challenge is definitely in keeping track of the characters as they morph through different identities and time lines, showing their range and diverse acting skills.  Almost feel like we need to watch it a few more times before we recognize the actors in their various roles.  This one's a keeper for the DVD collection.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I was very much looking forward to seeing Cloud Atlas and as soon as I could I blind purchased it. Do I regret it?Cloud Atlas is a commitment. It is not a movie you just pop in to be entertained, it is a film in which you dedicate almost three hours of your life to unraveling the complicated interwoven stories which may or may not be connected or may or may not spike your interest. I must admit, some of the stories did not interest me at all, however there was one or two which I really found interesting. Movies are meant to entertain and be popcorn flicks. Films are meant to tell a story and convey a message which the director and writer are trying to drill into your head.You really need to pay attention to Cloud Atlas. Not many films are like it, however movies like The Tempest come to mind where the film is very difficult to view and seemingly complicated when in actuality it is not. These movies are rare, original and beautifully complicated to a magnificent degree.The acting is great. The Blu-ray PQ & AQ is great and the over-all direction and presentation is spectacular. So what is lacking? The movie simply is so choppy it is difficult to watch, understand and comprehend. Part of me cannot wait to watch it again, however another part of me has no desire to view it again.Do I recommend blind buying it? No.Do I recommend renting it? Yes, very much so.Do I regret blind buying it? A little as I find it may be a very long time until I have the strength to watch it again.
summary: Original, Visionary, Complicated. Demands multiple viewings
Title: Cloud Atlas

Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: "Cloud Atlas" (2012 release; 172 min.) is a massively ambitious movie made by no less than 3 directors (Lana (nee Larry) Wachowski and Andy Wachowski from of course the Matrix trilogy, and Tom Tykwer from Run Lola Run). There are six separate stories in the movie, set in the 1840's Pacific, the 1930's Cambridge, the 1970's San Francisco, today's London, the 2100's Neo Seoul, and a post-apocalytic story set "106 winters after Fall". Because of the sheer size and volume of these separate stories, it took me about an hour into the movie to just get a handle less or more on what is happening. That is not a complaint. It is simply stating the epic parameters of the movie.It is truly impossible to bring a nice synopsis of these 6 different stories, and suffice to say that common themes eventually arise from these stories: "Our lives are not our own, we are all connected with others, past and present". This is of course emphasized in the fact that the lead actors perform multiple roles, none more so than Tom Hanks and Hale Berry, who star in all six stories. It is utter fun to see the transformation in the various roles, and for that my hat off to Hale Berry and the make-up team as she truly looks amazingly different in her different roles, including being a German (read: caucasion) Jewish woman, and even better as an Asian old man (yes, man!). Just wow. Also noteworthy is Hugh Grant, who appears in 4 or 5 (I lost track after a while) widely varying roles. Of all the stories, I liked the one set in 2144 in "Neo Seoul" the best, as it brings a Blade Runner-reminding atmosphere and of course the Wachowskis are right at home in such a futuristic setting (not just the Matrix but check also Speed Racer).If you think that you are in for a neat little wrap-up of everything at the end of the almosr 3 hr. movie, you might be wrong. Just for that fact, I'd love to see an alternative "cut" of this movie, in which the six stories are not "blended", as they are in the movie. I read somewhere that the production cost alone of this movie was about $100 million, making it the most expensive "indie" movie ever (it was financed primarily out of Germany, believe it or not). No way this movie will come anywhere close to that number at the box office in the US. All that aside, this is by no means a "bad" movie. It is an interesting experiment in which the ambition is greater than the execution. Viewers beware.
summary: 3.5 stars... "Our lives are not our own"
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: First of all, I dislike movies that let you see the obvious ending before they even start developing the plot...( too many of them out there ) Well, this is NOT one of them.  It takes a lot of corners, and keeps you abreast of how each change fits into the whole.  I would recommend this movie to anyone, not withstanding, its hard to find any Tom Hanks movie that isn't good anyway.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: You need to really concentrate when watching this delightful movie. The main characters are a joy to watch.Watch it again to make sure you understand and did not miss anything. It causes you to think.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I finally had an opportunity to see this movie and it is stunning. It is complex and brilliant and takes good while to start seeing how all the threads weave together into a single taperestry that is simultanously funny, heartbreaking, energizing and horrifying. It is NOT a check your brain at the door film and judging by the content of one and two star reviews I read here, more than a few people went into this start studded epic expecting brainless fare of the Micheal Bay "Transformers" variety. If you buy or rent it, watch it with the subtitles on, as it will make the future-speak parts easier to understand. Sprawling, complex and elegant...and like all films of this kind, requires more than one viewing to really take it all in.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cool idea, but very drawn out.  The effects were amazing, the plot was good, the acting was great.Only down side... Very long...
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Well I see some of our know-it-all reviewers have written novellas, so I will be brief as possible.I liked it.I will watch it again, not right away, but soon. Photography was beautiful, it is hard to follow in places, but that is the nature of the story. I found the make-up a little lacking in some places, very good in others.It depends on what you want, what you expect. Read some of those novellas, take the negative reviews with a grain of salt, and make up your own mind.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I movies that conceptualizes unlimited possibilities. It was inspiring. I enjoyed the idea that we are connected through time. Loved it
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This film has six stories that all have a common theme.  The fact that we are all connected and our actions have consequences that affect human history.  What I thought was going to be a downer of a film turned out to be a rare cinematic triumph!  As one reviewer said, you want to watch this with the captions to keep up with the future-speak in some segments.  Tom Hanks and Halle Berry give unforgettable performances as different characters.  Hugo Weaving also plays the role of the antagonist in many of the segments. My advice to any fan of the cinema would be: Go see it!  It's unlike anything you've ever seen before!
summary: Timeless film that will be remembered 50 years from now! A rare moment in Hollywood movie making!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Amazingly Cloud Atlas did not impress me too much. The story is kind of hard to follow and unless you really pay attention, you can understand that it's a continuous going back and front time travel depicting the life of two characters; the finale is a happy one. These four stars go to all the actors in the movie, that were so incredibly good at impersonating different roles to the point one would have hard time to recognize them. Don't miss it and don't miss the special effects, the action and ... yes I do recommend it.
summary: I Am Still in the Clouds
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I read the book, which I'm sure was helpful.  Plus I really liked the story, so I was looking forward to having the visuals to go with my memory of the story.  I was not disappointed, and my wife, who I thought might have trouble following it, actually really enjoyed it and has been asking friends if they have seen it yet.  It is really an excellent and unusual film with beautiful cinematography, great CGI, especially in the future time frames, and a very moving message.  The multiple characters for most actors was an added point of interest, and I thought it made it interesting and supported the underlying point.  See it if you haven't - it's truly great.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: That it all made sense in the end was brilliant. Loved the different disguises of the main actors. Loved the idea of repeated connections in many lifetimes.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: No doubt about it, Cloud Atlas is ambitious.  From cramming six stories into its three hours to having actors take on so many varied roles, it truly is a movie like no other and it's all the better for it. The film simply tells six stories, jumping around back and forth between the different stays.  What makes it work though is it helps the viewer see the connections they are trying to make.The beginning can be a little confusing until you figure out the structure.  Then it becomes very rewarding as the film starts to fall together in the end.  IT's coupled with some very amazing performaces, with Ben Whimshaws possibly being the standout dramatic performance.  The one who seems to be having the most fun is Hugo Weaving, who gets to play a femal nurse in one part.The visuals are stunning, from the ocean landscapes depicted in the 1800s to the futuristic Neo-Soul and the post apocolyptic world that followed.  The movie's on target and the locations are continually interesting throughout the film.  Kudos the directors for making the varied settings fun and authentic.Many reviewers remark on the confusing plot structure, but if you pay attention, it comes together.  As you piece it together, you'll be rewatching it to see all the nods each story pays to other parts of the story.  Many people who I've watched it want to rewatch it, and enjoy it even more the second time round.This was easily one of my favorite films of the year and it really got a raw deal from many critics.  But it's endlessy arresting and love it or hate it, you'll be talking about it afterwards.
summary: Underappreciated, I hope it finds a new life
Title: Cloud Atlas

Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I was fortunate enough to see this film in the theater, and my review is based off of that.  I head grumblings from various people about the very long run-time of the movie (around 3-1/2 hours), but that did not bother me, and actually I learned my lesson once before when I refused to go see "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" in the theater due to its length, and later viewed it on DVD and loved it.  So first off, don't let the length scare you off.  In this case, the length only enhances the experience, as you truly become engrossed in the story...I came out of the movie wanting more.Another negative I heard going in, was that the movie jumped around a lot, and that it was distracting and hard to follow.  True it did jump around a bit, between the different stories told in different time periods, but I found that neither hard to follow, nor distracting.  In fact, I found it masterful the way the stories all tied in to one another, and the flow of the story in and out of these periods kept my interest peaked at all times.  I hate to use the cliche that it is a "thinking person's movie", but it is.  It is not something to kill a few hours watching for something to do, it is an experience.The casting, the acting, the costume, and special effects were all great, and I would give them all 5-stars on their own, but it was none of those that made me enjoy this movie as much as I did, it was the story.  It was happy, it was sad, it was funny, it was inspiring, and it was action-packed, all in one (or should I say all in six).  I felt a real connection to the characters in this film, which I find to be rare these days.  This is a story for action fans, drama fans, sci-fi fans, thriller fans, it really is a story for a broad base of movie-goer.  The overall grandeur of the experience of this film was like few others for me, and I can honestly rank this in the top 10, maybe even top 5 movies I have seen, ever.  Do yourself a favor and buy this movie, because you will want to watch it again and again.
summary: Phenomenal movie, one of the best ever
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I am still waiting to get up enough boredom to have the desire to finish watching this movie. I hated the beginning, I hated the middle , so I have no doubt I will hate the end. Sometimes artists become lost in their craft to the displeasure that films are supposed to be made for audience enjoyment and not for the pleasure or acceptance of other artists. If there was anything entertaining about this film it was not for us stupid people. But unfortunately we are the ones who blindly pay to watch. I wish we could demand refunds!
summary: There Is A Cloud In This Title.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I would expect that everyone is already acquainted with the Hindu concept of reincarnation.  If we are reborn as people (and not as frogs or poodles) then we are destined to meet the same souls from our previous existence -- although your wife could be your daughter, your father could be your brother, etc.  The movie revolves around this belief, although someone helpful in world "A" could be someone who wants to kill you in world "B", etc.  A movie this broad hinges on being able to create strong bonds through times/worlds, and it fails to do that. With so many A-list actors onboard, you'd think the movie couldn't fail.  Wrong.  I couldn't see any reason for the film being nearly three hours long -- most people will find this to be a colossal bore. The only saving graces are the cinematography and the special effects. There is a very brief homosexual scene toward the beginning, and this alone caused a number of viewers to stop watching -- although their comments never actually identified what the big turn-off was about.  A much better metaphysical movie to watch is "The Fountain," which is far more artful and moving.  I gave "Cloud Atlas" a generous three stars because it is very ambitious and tries to be original.  I think if you go into it with an empty mind, you may find a few scenes that are engaging, but no guarantees.
summary: Not Half as Good as it Should Be
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The movie is a new play on an old theme . . . Reincarnation.  This time juxtaposed against mankinds natural depravity and the inevitable movement to tame that depravity and move humanity forward.  While making an entertaining movie, it's not a concept that carries any weight of possibility in it's hull.  It probably appeals to the dreamer in Tom Hanks and most of us, including me, but that appeal is to our species' narcissism.  In other words, we think it's all about us, and that we are so important that there is no way we can cease to exist for eternity.  Hence the reincarnation conception.  We embrace ideas that favor us most.If you have a scientific mind and truly care about the search for truth and reality, an entertaining movie is all this can be.  There is something to this universe that we still do not know.  It's likely that it teems with life and it's very purpose is the development of life.  But not just human life.  Whatever the "end" is, it includes all life and not just us.So the movie IS entertaining . . . And it makes you think.  That can't be a bad thing.
Title: Cloud Atlas

Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cloud Atlas, which alternates between six different time periods at an increasing rate throughout the movie, is one of those things that you think can never work, but then you come to see that it does, magnificently. It goes through several phases. First the setting up of each scenario: in the 1840s on the high seas, in the 1930s in Europe, in the 1970s in California, present-day England, a couple centuries hence in "Neo-Seoul", and a in primitive setting (initially) far in the future. In the first phase you start out confused, don't see how there can be any relation between the scenarios, and brace for two and a half hours of disappointment. But then, slowly, themes repeat, and it starts to come together. We fully enter the new phase where the scenario shifts start to occur much more quickly, and they are clever: each scene dovetails into the next from another time with a similar situation, or word or phrase, or theme, or physical location. Then all six stories start to reach their climaxes, and the time-switching switches into high gear. Here there's a lot of Wachowski-trademarked intense violence (although no slow-fast motion martial arts, a la The Matrix (well, close, in Neo-Seoul (get it? Neo?))). And then the denouements reveal the overall theme, which I will not attempt to summarize, and it becomes crystal clear. And it's beautiful. Cloud Atlas is probably a new entry into my top ten favorite movies of all time.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The effort that it took to put David Mitchell's book to film is monumental, and Mr. Tykwer and the Wachowski's have done a remarkable job to flesh out all the confusion. Multiple characters played by only a handful of actors give this film about the universal connection of people to each other a flair that blew me away. Every member of the cast is outstanding and I'll never understand why this was so ignored when awards were given out. Brilliant acting, editing, cinematography and special effects, as well as every other element to detail provided were, to me at least, a comprehensive and complete story about where man has been and where he's destined to go.It's esoteric in it's approach, but not too hard to understand if you pay attention. I really believe all involved--actors, directors, crews--gave it their all, and I'm pleased, very pleased, to have this in my collection for repeated viewings.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cloud Atlas is nearly three hours long.  During my viewing, I never regretted the length.  Not once did I get impatient for the movie to end.  This movie is actually many stories woven into a single film.  The film held my attention for its' full length.  I even stayed around for the credits to listen to the movies beautiful (and relevant) theme music.  For me to be engrossed in anything for three hours straight is amazing.  But Cloud Atlas is an extraordinary film.  Hollywood enough to keep your adrenalin pumping but European\cosmopolitan enough to cause you to think about the movies content and wonder at the story's moral.  I think Cloud Atlas is a popular film masterpiece.

Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This is a movie that is both fun and will speak to you in its own voice, and in many voices, and on many levels.  I was somewhat prepared for it from reading a few of that reviews that cautioned (welcomed or criticized) its unconventional structure.  The polarization of the professional reviews it received was telling.  As many who liked it have said, it is a film that will be worth watching again.  The performances of everyone involved with this move - from directing, to acting, to editing, to production design, to special effects, to music are all amazing.  Forget what you know about watching or telling a conventional story - and enjoy the way that multiple stories are told, intertwined, and contrasted here.  If a simple story is linear and one dimensional, and a movie with flash backs or ensemble stories is two dimensional, then this film is truly multi dimensional, with links along, between, and across the stories that are told.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This movie is 6 stories and 600 years. It is also almost 3 hours long. Watching this movie is like a weekend project. You will have to really pay attention to remember all 6 stories and how they are connected. Pay close attention during the closing credits for the multiple roles of each actor. Tom Hanks and Halle Berry both played 7 roles each. Males played females and females played males. Even though it may be difficult to follow just the visuals will keep you entertained for the entire movie. Watch it with breaks and you will never forget it.
summary: I have never seen anything quite like it.
Title: Cloud Atlas

Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Having not read the book "Cloud Atlas", my opinion is untainted by impressions of the often-times superior novel.The story as presented was a little confusing, edging ever so closely to tedious... a miriad of tales, seemingly disconnected and spanning centuries, involving cultures and places both familiar and foreign. But what made the journey comfortable was great acting, superb sound, scenery and cinematography, and the effects. I am predicting more than one nomination come Oscar time."Cloud Atlas" is truly a feast for the senses. It's not so much a film as it is an experience... something not only to be seen but felt.A good gauge as to the entertainment value of this film is the fact that despite the confusion I felt in not really knowing where the story was leading me, I remained riveted for the nearly 3 hours and barely moved in my seat. I guess what may best illustrate this is taking a cross-country train trip versus flying. It takes longer to reach the final destination, but the scenery makes it well worth the time.
summary: Whew! A feast for the mind and the senses! And I'm stuffed!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: about slavery.  They could had left that sailing shipout.  It served no purpose and was boring.  Had they done more with the futuristic segment, this would have been a great movie. Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cloud Atlas(released Sept/12)contains a plethora of stars,amongst which are,Tom Hanks,Halle Berry,Jim Broadbent,Hugo Weaving,Jim Sturgess,Doona Bae,Ben Whishaw,James D'Arcy,Susan Sarandon and Hugh Grant.There are six stories here ranging from the 19th century to the 24th.The first is a doctor whose trip to the South Pacific on behalf of his father convinces him slavery is wrong.The second finds a gay composer teaming up with an old and renowned musician,only to take his own life.The third sees a reporter investigating what will ultimately turn out to be a scandal of collusion between an oil company and a nuclear energy firm.The fourth is about a book publisher who is locked up in a nursing home by his brother,only to escape and write his autobiography.The fifth is in Korea in the future where a restaurant worker is freed and she sees what her societal"norms"are truly based upon.Can you say"Soylent Green"? The last vignette is even farther into the future and a poor tribesman with many an inner demon,is assisted by someone from the outside,which leads them both to a better life.It is a grand film full of wishes of grandeur and scope,but I found it's tales of lives affecting future ones,and railing against authority and doing the right thing a little old and stale.It is a film told with different vignettes and these seemingly disparate stories it imparts are ultimately all connected.Many of the actors playing in each one are sometimes unrecognizable at first glance due to heavy makeup.It is a film you really have to stick to,especially in the beginning,as it excruciatingly lumbers along starting one story and jumping to another.As the film progresses the stories become ever that much closer and the jumping's shorter and swifter.But as I say,in the end,all I could do was shrug my shoulders and say:"That was it? All that for a LONG 170 minutes or so of my time?".Technically speaking the film is in its original w/s a/r of 2:35:1 and it is generally crisp and clear.The colours in many of the stories have been manipulated to produce a stronger and striking contrast while viewing.Extras are one featurette.All in all,if tales of fighting against authority,doing the right thing,all mixed up with a little reincarnation turn your crank,then this one is for you.But I found it's story and story hopping tedious at best and its' length horrifically too long.Not recommended.2-2 1/2 stars.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Possibly the best movie I've ever seen.  Several interconnected, interwoven stories spanning thousands of years which very subtly draws a picture of our interconnectedness and interdependence, of the consequences of our actions.  It is a very rich and multifaceted story with many of the actors playing several roles of both genders and doing so seamlessly with brilliant restraint and understatement.  The film will make you want to see it again.  I have seen it three times and would love multiple additional viewings.  Perfectly balanced presentation of drama, comedy and action.
summary: Possibly the best film I've ever seen.

reviewText: Kira at Bashi.  Rai and Jiri at Lungha. Rai of Lowani. Lowani under two moons. Jiri of Ubaya. Ubaya of crossroads, at Lungha. Lungha, her sky gray.  Darmok and Jalad at Tanagra.  Darmok on the ocean.  Kiteo, his eyes closed.  Temba, his arms wide/open.  Mirab, with sails unfurled.  Zinda, his face black, his eyes red.  Chenza at court, the court of silence.  Shaka, when the walls fell.  Sokath, his eyes uncovered/opened.  Never.

But anyway. I don't think I could sit through this again.......unless....somebody could explain to me what I missed that connected these stories all together,  because, the best thing that happened to me in this film is that it did eventually finally end. Oh, Thank God!
summary: If the novel was good, it didn't carry over to film very well

reviewText: The acting is excellent but the plot is hard to follow as it ping pongs back and forth from one time to another.  It's a movie you need to see a second time just so you can sort it out and perhaps follow it a bit easier.  It wouldn't be a great sacrifice to watch it a second time as the characters are fascinating because they are played by the same actors....crossing race and gender lines in different times and eras.  It's interesting to see if you can look through the ingenious makeup and identify what character the actor is playing for that time.  It's definately worth a shot.

reviewText: This review is after my first time watching this film.  I was a little worried by the lower rated posts on this film, but decided to give it a chance.  I was pleasantly surprised.  I found the story easy to follow, and quite sweet.  I didn't even realize the time had gone by as it had.  Unfortunately, the pasta I was making during the film didn't make it.  It was worth the sacrifice.  I can understand that people that have gotten used to the new style Hollywood movies that couldn't care less if it had a plot or theme, might have a hard time of following along. I wouldn't say this is award material, but definitely one that I'm glad I watched and I would probably watch again, though not too far in the near future.  Tom Hanks did an admirably good job.  I thought the beginning where he had his monologue did not bode well for the movie, but he progressed so well I forgot about it until writing the review.  Holly Barry also did a smart job.  Not as good as Hanks, but worthy.  I feel she represented herself quite well, and I must say she's done better than expected.  I'm looking forward to her next character. Jim Broadbent was of course amazing.  He's always been able to harness a character to the fullest.  Hugo Weaving was surprising in this one.  He also is a maverick when it comes to different characters.  I especially loved when he was suddenly Nurse Noakes!  OMG!  Loved it!!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The first time I watched this film I had to watch it again right away!  It had an epic scale with a complex plot interweaving the threads of a variety of lives with wonderful performances by an excellent cast!  i like having the DVD so i can speed through the most violent scenes (not sure that degree of violence was vital to the plot) but the excellence of the over-all production brings me back again and again.  In my top 5 favorite films of all time.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I rather liked it once I did straighten out the different stories being weaved in an out and seeing the thread(s) that tied them, thematically, together.  So I'm surely going to watch this again a few times.  I ended up liking the switching back and forth between stories.  I do admit I started watching this on a plane ride and gave up.  However, the environment on the plane (including the tiny screen) was not conducive to concentration and thought.  (I had a better time with "Life of Pi" on a plane because, at least, the story is nice and linear for the most part.  However, watching this film at home was also much better.)I will say that I thought about a "3" for this, but, since I would watch it again and again at least a few times and admire the design, I gave it a "4".
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cloud Atlas is a good film that could have been a great film if it had not been so confusing and inconsistent. Allow me to elaborate further. The film did have MANY positive, appealing aspects to it, it was visually stunning, had many rich and interesting characters, both good and bad, as well as very strong spiritual themes such as reincarnation and the belief that there is a bond that connects us all. However, the fact that it kept switching back and forth, changing characters, style of dialogue, and even tone (some stories were more humorous or dramatic than others), it almost felt like I was watching six separate movies instead of one cohesive one. I understand that all of the stories are connected and feature the same actors/actresses so it's obviously meant to be just one film, the settings and tones, as previously mentioned, were so diverse and different that I still had trouble connecting them to the other stories. One story, the 19th century one, felt like a historical adventure film a la Pirates of the Caribbean, The story that takes place in the far future, with Tom Hanks and Halle Berry meeting up in a setting which oddly reminded me of Battlestar Galactica, seems like a Sci-Fi epic similar to Avatar or Star Wars and the story that takes place in modern times seems like something Guy Ritchie or Shane Meadows would direct. It was all very inconsistent and very unnecessary. However, I greatly did enjoy all of the actors playing such wildly different characters, especially Tom Hanks, who plays both very villainous and very heroic roles, demonstrating how he eventually redeems himself of his past sins and negative karma. I have heard this film described as a very "Buddhist" film and I certainly agree, many of the central themes of Buddhism such as karma, reincarnation, dharma, and samsara. I feel that there aren't enough films of this sort being made nowadays and I greatly enjoyed watching it. Cloud Atlas is no masterpiece, at least in my view, but neither is it pretentious or overwrought, it's just an enjoyable film which I'm glad I managed to watch in all it's roughly 3 hour running time. Thank you and have a nice day.
summary: An original, ambitious film that never reaches it's full potential
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I somewhat "enjoyed" this movie.  Overall story line was a bit confusing, but I got the "jist" of it.  Very thought provoking to say the least. I'm just glad that I got refunded due to poor viewing quality.  Maybe the movie itself second guessed it's worthiness?

Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Alright, in a nutshell this movie is for people with ADD, I kid not.How can a movie pushing three hours in length be ideally suited for people suffering from Attention Deficit Disorder?Well let's see, most scenes are about two to three minutes long and jump back and forth from time lines and characters constantly.As I watched this I realized that I could not get tired of this long movie because there's all these little cliffhangers every couple of minutes leading from one scenario to the next.This movie is long but you might not feel it one bit.As for the story this is all about the metaphysical stuff and as usual when presented this way, the message is somewhat mangled by all the special effects used to pacify those that just don't get it.Like probably everybody whose watched this movie.If anybody knows or thinks they know what the moral of the story is by all means let me know.Now some scenes are just downright breath taking, like the futuristic city and for that I could understand some one buying Cloud Atlas, but another reason is to watch it a few more times to see what may have been missed in the first viewing, as this is a meaty movie to say the least.As for me I'm glad I watched once and will probably need to watch again soon.Oh and the acting as you can probably guess judging by the roster is of course top notch from all involved.Definitely worth checking out.

reviewText: It is a bit hard to describe this movie and do it justice.  It is simply one where you need to sit down and strap in.  It follows through six different storylines with most of the main cast portraying about five to six different characters each.  What I found amazing is how each story feeds into and off of another.  There are touchstones and symbols that connect to each other.  It is great to watch the end credits to actually see all the characters each actor portrayed; some will surprise you.  I do encourage viewing this movie more than once as sometimes things can slip by.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I have not read the book, but judging by book reviews and previews for the movie, I really expected to like this. Instead, all I found it to be was a purposefully confused, often boring mess. Good storytelling doesn't have to force itself to be obtuse, and it needs to convey a point. This movie seemed mostly pointless.  It was also unnecessarily gory a few times, and I never appreciate that.I will give it credit for its makeup though.  Holy cow; a few times it was quite a while before I realized which (famous) actor was behind a particular character's makeup job.  But that's about all I can give it credit for.
summary: I will give it credit for its makeup.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cloud Atlas is a conspiracy thriller, a dystopian science fiction story, a high seas adventure, a jovial geriatric comedy, a post apocalyptic action-adventure, to say nothing of the many love stories intertwined, but above it is a deeply moving human story. Cloud Atlas is hard to describe and  difficult to pigeon hole, but one thing I do know is that it is unlike anything  I have seen before  and it is one of the best movies I have ever seen.This is a feast for the moviegoer, a joy to behold as many different movies play out in front of you. None are necessarily better than the other, and they are all great. Fascinating, exciting and funny in equal measures, a full experience at the movies if ever their was one. You'll need to keep your eyes on this thorough, it will be easy to get lost in the engulfing abyss of shear splendor, but it all becomes clear and actually isn't difficult to follow.There are those who insist that Cloud Atlas is an empty vessel lacking in depth and substance. I couldn't disagree more, to me their was a great deal of deep feelings and thoughts stirred in my head. Certainly not for all tastes, but what movie is, each viewer will have a different reaction to this film, for some it will be very rewarding.  A movie is  different things to different people and to me this is a multifaceted and meditative experience.To try and summarize the plot would be an exercise in futility, as so much is always going on here in this accelerating non-linear epic that spans the period from 1849 until 2349. Cloud Atlas is absorbing and succeeds at the delicacy of avoiding pretension. It is bold and challenging and at nearly three hours is a marvel in it's ability to never seem a second too long. Filled with wondrous possibilities and telling a grandiose story filled with hope, redemption, passion and love.I have always felt that a good test of any actor's ability is to see them play more than a single character in a film because it gives you a clear idea regarding their range and ability to slip in and out of various roles. Here a fine cast with Tom Hanks, Halle Berry, Jim Broadbent, Hugh Grant, Susan Sarandon, Jim Sturges, Ben Whishaw, James D'Arcy, Hugo Weaving, Doona Bae, among others are at the very pinnacle of their talent, they get to shine in about six roles each, one in each story for most of them.The make-up effects are some of the very best I have ever had the pleasure of feasting my eyes on. The actors manage to effortlessly metamorphoses into a dizzying array of characters thanks to this incredible make-up job provide by twenty-six immensely talented artists. After some recent bad make-up jobs seriously impaired some contemporary movies, I'm looking at you  J. Edgar, such an awe-inspiring job is fantastically refreshing. I am usually pretty sharp at spotting actors under make-up, especially very well know stars, but I have to admit that I know I couldn't tell who all the actors were at any given time. Some people may be distraction by attempts to spot all the actors, but that is ineffective as the stars themselves have admitted in interviews to not always recognizing one another, and the movie is so easy to get caught up in as to forget to keep stargazing.It took three directors, Andy and Lana Wachowski and Tom Tykwer, to successfully bring this highly ambitious movie together. Three talented filmmakers for sure, but until know they have all emphasized a style over substance attitude. Each have taken and seized the sections of this movie that best caters to their abilities, for example Tyker has taken on the suspense and lighter stories, while the Wachowskis focuss their attention on the action and science fiction elements. This is a very wise thing to do and helps to make it fully clear the need for all three to work in conjunction, I`m not sure any one director, no matter how talented could be able to pull this film off. Their achievements are to be commended and the fact that they realize something so well is staggering.I was not a fan of the Wachowskis going into this, I hated Speed Racer and was always a wet blanket when it came to their immensely popular Matrix trilogy. Cloud Atlas reminds me that at first they showed a great deal of promise with Bound, a smart and edgy thriller that couldn't have been more different than Cloud Atlas, but with Cloud Atlas they have graduated to the level of greatness and first rate filmmakers.This thrilling epic is based on an award winning and Nebula nominated "unflimable" masterpiece of a novel by David Mitchell. Adapted by the three directors, the film is quite different in many respects to the author's book, the movie is more passionate and emphasizing the reincarnation motif. Mitchell has praised the filmmakers for playing to the strengths of their medium that is decidedly different from his.The movie is lovingly photographed by Frank Griebe and John Toll. Griebe handles Tykwers's parts, the two are long time collaborators going back to their German-language contemporary classic Run Lola Run. Toll works the Wachowskis and is one of the best cinematographers today having won an Oscar for his beautiful work on Mel Gibson's Braveheart.For sure Cloud Atlas will leave people dived, some will find it brilliant while others will find it to be maddening. I will say that you wont soon forget it, and if your like me you'll become nearly obsessed by it and will want to see it again almost immediately. For others once will be too much, there loss.I don't know that Cloud Atlas will change anyone's belief system, or that it's aim is anything of the sort, but I think that it will challenge viewers to think, and for any movie that is a remarkable thing. You wont want to miss it, even if you wont like it, it's an experience worth having.  A perfect marriage of art, ambition and entertainment.see my reviews at moviezonemagazine.com
summary: one of the year's very best, beatiful and gloriously ambitious
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: a great look at our potential future and inside the reality of our lives, the synchronicity of souls, and the possibilities that lie ahead of us. worth seeing, if anything, for an escape from normalcy.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The whole premise of the movie is about a person having past lives with the premise that in the next one mistakes won't be repeated.  The movie shifts from one reincarnation to the other rapidly and doesn't tie each one together all that well.  Hanks plays several characters and not convincingly.  This is not a good role for Barry although she is better than Hanks.  Often the words are garbled by Hanks so you can't understand what he is saying, especially at the beginning of the movie.  The premise is just not plausible unless, of course, one believes in that stuff.  Not much action and the plots for each life are not worth the trouble.  Don't purchase this one.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Mild Alert - Some general thematic spoilers to those who haven't seen the movie yet, but no specific plot spoilers.I and my wife saw this monstrosity in the theater yesterday. My wife liked it. I decided to sleep on it before writing this review to be as fair as possible and see if my negative feelings about it survived a good night's sleep.Until yesterday, the most disastrous mess of a movie I had ever seen was Heaven's Gate.  But I actually like Heaven's Gate because there are portions of it that approached and maybe even achieved movie greatness, and that at least mitigated the truly disastrous majority of that movie.  My dear wife's opposing opinion notwithstanding, I can see no such mitigation for Cloud Atlas. It is by far, in my opinion, the most presumptuous Hollywood mess of a disaster that I have ever seen.It is unintelligible from the very beginning, and you are well into it before realizing that it is a time-jumping morass. It just does not work as a movie. Granted, I saw on the ending credits that the movie is based on a book. I am perfectly willing to believe that it works as a novel. In fact, I am seriously considering reading the book now to satisfy my curiosity of how faithful the movie version is to the book.  But not having read the book, here is a compendium of what I was thinking as I sat through this utterly mind numbing event, fidgeting through the long minutes while waiting for it to mercifully end (apologies to other reviewers who obviously have a very different opinion, judging by the early 4 and 5 star reviews here):* "This monstrosity is unintelligible. Must be another Hollywood example of: `different' = `creative'. Look at how `brilliant' the director is!" - As I've already mentioned, unless you arrive knowing the basic premise of the story/plot, the first parts of the movie are utterly unintelligible. Speaking of the word "plot", there is none really, although I realized by the end of the movie that there is a "story" of sorts.* "Typical Hollywood liberalism on display."-  The first love scene is of a gay couple and, by the time Cloud Atlas ends, the uber-enemy of all mankind is revealed to be Big Oil (by name!) and other profit-making corporations. And, of course, there are ample references to the rising sea levels, no doubt caused by global warming, which, in a giant loop of logic, is no doubt caused by the aforementioned Big Oil. Oh yes. To be fair, I don't know yet if the typical liberal propaganda is original to the book or if it was gratuitously inserted by Hollywood. If it's from the book, then it is certainly no fault of this movie's creators.* "Cartoonish. Yet one more example of Hollywood's over-reliance on CGI to hype interest when plot is weak or non-existent." - I was thinking this especially during the parts that take place in Korea or Japan (not exactly sure which country the "fabricants" portions take place in). For me, the CGI car chases and shootouts were not only badly done, but were also particularly jarring in view of the fact that most of the rest of the movie takes place in the "real" world. The juxtaposition of cartoon and reality just didn't work for me. Sorry! (If I may be facetious for a moment, movies like "Who Killed Roger Rabbit" did that kind of thing much more successfully. ;-))* "There is no rhyme, reason or logic to the jumbled sequence of vignettes that this movie consists of." - One normally expects that the order of scenes in a play, movie or novel is intentional and designed to clarify a story for the audience or move a story forward. Except for the opening and closing scenes with Tom Hanks as the movie's "narrator" for want of a better word, the entire rest of the movie's scenes could have been in any random order (and indeed, are). Even in retrospect, I see no overall logic for the movie's sequence of events or scenes.* "This movie's major themes have been done often and have ALWAYS been done better." - Two majorly MAJOR themes of the movie are 1) every event and everyone are connected, ripples in time, that sort of thing and 2) Love transcends time through reincarnations. Each theme is so OVERLY done and so shoved down the audience's throat that it loses all effectiveness as a new "angle" or new way to look at it. My take, when a director or screenwriter has to make his/her point with a sledgehammer, it's as good as an admission that the storyline is weak.* "The whole ultimate point of this movie seems to be a lot of New Age platitudes and tripe." - I'll leave it at that. This thought came to me towards the end of the movie and, depending on your personal belief system, that may be a plus or a minus for you.* Finally, "The bottom line message of this movie is an optimistic one, so I certainly wouldn't object to anyone of R-rated age seeing it. But neither would I recommend that they subject themselves to the torture."Well, that's my take and, at least as of this date, I seem to be in the minority here. I will, however mention that we saw Cloud Atlas in a large Imax theater on a Saturday. I expected a full house, but we walked in 15 minutes before showtime to an almost empty theater! There were two people seated when we walked in, and by the time the movie started only a handful of others had joined the four of us. Cloud Atlas has been out for about a week. If this is indicative of its box office going into its second week, I am wondering if the "real world" is staying away from this "stinker" notwithstanding the 4-5 star reviews posted here.  Full disclosure, we went to an afternoon screening. Maybe the evening showings were better attended. Still...Imax...Saturday matinee...first run movie with science fiction and video game elements usually attractive to a male teen audience  - I wouldn't normally expect an empty theater under those circumstances. I don't know how much the studio spent on this clunker (judging from the A-list cast and significant CGI investment it probably wasn't cheap to make), but I think they may lose money on the deal. Having begun with Heaven's Gate, let me close the circle - I have read that Heaven's Gate bombed so badly it bankrupted its studio. Might Cloud Atlas similarly shake the foundations of its backers?
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: From the first trailer I saw of this film, I knew it was unique. I became even more intrigued when I read the various reactions to it; I tend to enjoy most films that divide audiences. I missed it in the theaters, but figured it was deep enough to warrant acquiring unseen. But I didn't expect to like it as much as I did.... in fact, I loved it, so much that I started watching it again right after it ended.Probably the reason for that was the very experience of watching six stories unfold simultaneously in one sitting. Even though I had no problem getting drawn into and following each one, I did feel I needed a little refresher for things I might have missed at the outset. When you do that with this film, you notice little things that reference the other stories, foreshadowing bits, numerous "Aha" moments and recurring elements like the comet birthmark, the composer's music playing at a social function, relationships between specific actors' characters proving significant in different incarnations (deja-vu anyone?), etc. This is no leave-your-mind-at-the-door type of entertainment; this is an engage your mind deeply for the full 175 minutes because everything matters on multiple levels aural experience.As mentioned, six plots: In 1849 an attourney travels to Chatham Islands to conduct a business arrangement. While there he falls ill, is cared for by a rather shady doctor and on the way back discovers a stowaway slave in his quarters who convinces him to persuade the ship's captain to let him join the crew. A special friendship results. In 1936, an English musician (and hopeful composer) is hired by an older famous composer to help him overcome obstacles to his productivity; soon it becomes apparent that the older man wants to use the younger's own compositional gifts for his own legacy which develops into struggle for personal integrity. In 1973 a woman journalist finds herself drawn into some unsavory dealings between the oil industry and a nuclear power plant, with life threatening results. In 2012, a gangster who just published a book murders a high profile critic, good news for his publisher who enjoys all the profits after the guy goes to prison.... until the thug's former associates (probably characters in the book) show up at his place demanding what they consider their cut. He doesn't have quite as much as they demand, so he goes to his brother for help.... which ends up being a HUGE mistake. On ahead to 2144, in Neo-Seoul, Korea, a young female clone named Sonmi-451 who was genetically engineered for a lifetime of servitude is given a crash course in what it means to have a real life when a series of events partners her up with the rebel commander of a movement known as Union. She quickly becomes a person of great historical consequence. And in 2321 (introduced as "106 Winters After the Fall"), a member of a tribal society called The Valley reluctantly agrees to escort a visiting female member of a more technically advanced society, The Prescients, to a forbidden mountain temple known as Cloud Atlas, which the Valley tribe considers evil. Braving an enemy tribe of cannibals and an dark presence referred to as Old Georgie, a life-changing revelation awaits.And what's it all about? Well, the film's poster simply states "Everything Is Connected". That is the theme. Indeed, through attentive watching, many connections are emphasized, and easy to miss if one looks away too long. Another synopsis: "An exploration of how the actions of individual lives impact one another in the past, present and future". Essentially, to call this film an epic would be an understatement, and it's really up to the viewers and their willingness to ride out the journey to decide for themselves what it's "about". It will resonate with people differently, and many won't get it and tell you it's a bad film because of that. One thing for certain: For a film of this scope, I've never seen one that was better edited. The way it holds together alone is worthy of praise.One challenge I had with watching was picking up the dialect used by the Valley tribesmen, obviously an imagining of how language might evolve over the ages (see Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome); some viewers may find that taking getting used to. The onscreen performances are spot on, visual effects (and visuals overall) are seamless, and the makeup used to transform actors across characters (in some cases across genders) is a star in itself. One possible improvement would have been to use actual Korean actors across the board in the Neo-Seoul segment, the only not very convincing makeup I noticed. In no way did that diminish my enjoyment of the movie.Apparently this is not a film for everyone. People will either get it or not, perhaps be turned off by certain plot elements enough to want to shut the whole film out. I am with the group that considers it one of the best films ever, as much a departure from studio system dreck as a viewer hungry for originality could want. I don't hand out five star ranks to many movies. Cloud Atlas is perfect enough.
Title: Cloud Atlas
