Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: few films ever capture my sense of thought the unique way in which this film took me punching my lights out  the intricacy of all of the bobbing and weaving had me say wtf much before i should have but enough of that the actors themselves to the brilliance of this epic of a story that a writer assumed couldnt be explored in such magnitude as this  the production people did a masterful job at lacing the whole thing together  that was as they mind boggling in its scope alone so those who didnt get it dont try to consume the whole of its parts this will never work instead design for yourself a cheat sheet so you can follow along  having now seen the film  i have to say to score the film poorly is truly appalling to discredit what has been accomplished  if they dont get it dont discredit those who do a critic is just stab in the dark if on the other hand the critic holds to a prvios gripe he will more than likely keep it the film stands alone as a masterpiece
summary: powerful thought provoking incesssant in its scope tracks well not for everybody due to the fact you have to want to track it
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: you known some things and boundaries just shouldn't be crossed and this movie is a good example of that. Unnatural, abhorrent. That about sums it up.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I wanted to like this a lot more than I could. It was hard to follow the film. I liked the premise, the actors and the cinematography.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I am an older movie goer, in my early 60s.  I grew up watching b&w tv on only 3 channels.  I am probably not the target audience for Cloud Atlas, but I think it is a great film.  I will watch it several times, once the Blu-ray price drops, even though it is over two and a half hours long.  It is the "fastest" long movie I have ever watched.  The real star is the editing together of the various stories--truly marvelous.  I should admit I am a big fan of artful editing.  Pulp Fiction, Lone Star, and Memento are among my favorite films.  I am not a big fan of Tom Hanks, but he is brilliant in each of the roles he inhabits here.  You could appreciate this film just by watching him closely.  I highly recommend Cloud Atlas.  Not everyone will like it, but it deserves a greater audience than it found in the theater.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: My husband and I were looking forward to watching this movie as all of the movies we had watched with Tom Hanks starring in them were superb.  Not so with this one.  Although his acting skills were beyond reproach, the plot was difficult to follow from the beginning and the language used was not Tom Hanks' level.  The ending was also anticlimactic.  We were very disappointed.
summary: Movie Not Rated in the Clouds for Us
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: after the first few minutes, I got up and walked out of the room. however, my husband, who is blind, had read the book and wanted to keep watching and this movie does not have descriptive video. I had been nagging him to watch it so I went back and got entranced by the movie. it hangs together well and once I got past the extreme violence, it was a great movie.watch the credits so you get to see exactly how many roles each of these actors play. bet you can't figure them all out!!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This was the first film done by the Wachowski Siblings that really doesn't have any trickery inside it. The film in and of itself was good and worth watching especially when it gets to it's end. It wasn't their best film, but, it definitely was a good and great film. I loved the ending. It's the type of goodness that wasn't really mixed with that many trick ways of being and thinking. It's good and was in the remembrance of the good that I was raised with as a child. This just really was the first film that they've ever done without any tricks in it. It was good, especially at the end! They didn't use what they know for bad this time, they used what they know this time, for good!! Slow at times, but, very good!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The actors were good as it gave them a chance to "act" but the story line was pitiful and very hard to follow
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Very unusual story but I had to keep watching it. Would like to watch it again sometime. Some movies you can watch more than once. This is one of those
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I hated this movie, I found it so boring. I thought, about 30 minutes in,  I will never be able to make it through.  So I certainly understand all the negative reviews here.And then, I do not remember when, I realized that I was still watching. And all of a sudden the magnificent musical score drew me in more and more. Actually, I never quite knew what I was watching, And, personally,  I did not care. I have never had an experience quite like it.  I stopped figuring it out. My mind and heart opened. And by the end of the film, I was so deeply moved, I was shocked. I had tears running down my cheeks.  What a breathtaking piece of filmmaking.  It was beyond worthwhile to me that I chose to keep watching it.  One of the most profoundly moving films I have ever seen
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I thought it was very confusing.It was cool that they played all these different parts.But i thought it was very hard to follow.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: "Our lives are not our own. From womb to tomb, we are bound to others. Past and present. And by each crime and every kindness, we birth our future." This is usually the part where I give a little synopsis of what the movie is about before I give my opinion. The problem with this one is that I don't think I'm smart enough to tell you what the movie is about, mainly because I'm not 100% sure. I do know it's about how the life of one person affects others throughout time, but after that I don't know what to say. I'm sure many will figure it out and think I'm dumb for not catching on though. As far as what I thought about it...to me there was just too much of everything. The movie is basically little vignettes of characters that are supposedly connected to the others but it jumps around so much its hard to follow. Most movies like this have one main plot line they follow and branch off of that...this one just put them all together and I had a hard time following. The other big distraction was the make-up. I do like the way they had the same actors in each section to show their point but the whole time I was thinking...I think that's Hugh Grant, or is that Agent Smith? It seemed to take me out of the movie. It may seem like I'm bashing this movie but the truth is I couldn't follow it enough to form a real opinion. I will admit that by the end I thought I was following it a little better but this is one I am not smart enough for. Overall, to me this is another movie where the writers and directors try to prove they are artsy and smarter then the audience...congratulations...you win. I give it a C+
summary: A movie I found very hard to follow and understand. The jumping around and make-up was distracting to me. I say C+
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: A dozen different disconnected storyline in a dozen disconnected settings, featuring dozens of people speaking unintelligible gibberish in monotonic voices and absurd idiosyncratic dialects with absolutely no hint of a singular purpose to it all, even after the first 45 minutes...Well, that is all I can stand.  Tom Hanks has made a lot of boring films, but this one goes beyond boring.  This farce is definitely for that select group of hipster/posers that thought "Lost" was good drama with "deep insight and profound meaning".  Two thumbs down.If you can find a written review with full spoilers that can be read in less than two minutes, you will have saved yourself some considerable agony by reading it and then passing this film by.On the other hand, of course, if you are the sort of person who feels compelled to agree with those who feel that Carl Jung and Edgar Cayce were brilliant men of science out of a need for "belonging", then this movie is probably ripe for you. After all, the book was written for the herd, and this movie was made to capitalize on that herds' bankroll.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Who among us doesn't want to be remembered? To make an impact that will last lifetimes? It turns out everyone's life does, just not necessarily the way you might like or to the degree you might hope, or so says this latest offering from the creators of The Matrix trilogy based on a novel of the same name by David Mitchell.Chronologically, the first character we're introduced to is Adam Ewing. Ewing (played by Jim Sturgess) is an American lawyer travelling to the South Pacific to conduct business on behalf of his father-in-law. He witnesses the enslavement of the native islanders, offers passage to one who stows away on the ship, Autua (played by David Gyasi) and falls ill as a result of exposure to a parasite. Once incapacitated by his illness, Ewing is "cared for" by the maniacal Dr. Henry Goose (played by Tom Hanks). Eighty-seven years later, we're taken to the UK and introduced to a young man whose wealthy father sees him as an embarrassment and has disowned him. That man, Robert Frobisher (played by Ben Whishaw), dreams of being a composer. While hoping to achieve that, he takes a job dictating for a man whose already achieved fame of his own, Vyvyan Ayrs (played by Jim Broadbent), whose eyes are failing him. Despite Ayrs unpleasant demeanor, Frobisher proves up to the job and it allows him time to further his own ambitions. Flash forward another thirty-seven years, we meet Luisa Rey. Rey (played by Halle Berry who also portrays relatively minor characters in the previous storylines) is a second-generation journalist writing a story about a nuclear power plant that is opening in her hometown of San Francisco. Unexpectedly, she meets Rufus Sixsmith (former lover of the now-deceased Frobisher played by James D'Arcy). Sixsmith (D'Arcy) is a nuclear physicist who knows that the plant is unsafe and hopes to relay his knowledge to Rey and provide evidence to substantiate it. What neither Ray, Sixsmith, or Dr. Isaac Sachs (another whistleblower played by Tom Hanks) are aware of however, is that they are all being hunted by a man whose employers wish to see the plant open, no matter the risk to the environment or local residents. Once again, we jump ahead. This time, thirty-nine years to the present. There we meet Timothy Cavendish (played by Broadbent). Cavendish is a publisher at a publicity event for an author named Dermot Hoggins (Hanks). During the event, Hoggins sees a critic who panned his work and throws him off the balcony. While he is sent to jail for his actions, his book begins flying off the shelves resulting in a financial windfall for Cavendish. Members of the Hoggins family wish to take the proceeds Cavendish is receiving from the sales as a result of Dermot signing away his rights to them before going to jail. Cavendish goes on the run and his brother Denholme (played by Hugh Grant who, like the others, played roles of varied significance in the previous stories) sends him to an establishment that he mistakes for a hotel but that is, in fact, a secure home for the elderly. Rather than capitulate, Cavendish plots his escape with help from other unhappy residents, one of whom only says two words over and over during the planning of the escape and the escape itself.There are two more storylines which, together, span a time of two-hundred nine years into the future. Rather than describe them both, I'll simply conclude here with my thoughts on the film as a whole. Cloud Atlas, while not as brilliant as the hype made it out to be, is a great film. Hanks and company play all of their roles expertly. And though the connective tissue between them strains credulity at times, they each leave the viewer with a sense of hope and optimism that, in the end, things will work out somehow. That's not a large part of my particular worldview, but it's beautifully depicted and highly entertaining, nonetheless. See it.
summary: Not as good as Cast Away, but...
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Like it or loathe it, one must admit that this film is an impressive achievement.  To deny this fact is cynicism maybe even hateration.  The Wachowski's have filmed the un-filmable for a pittance as compared to current blockbusters.  There are moments of breathtaking emotion - as when Sonmi, a 22nd century synthetic servant girl has her neck collar removed.  There are moments of pure and astounding cinema - as when the slave unfurls the main sail of the ship upon which he has stowed away in hopes of earning legal passage or when Ms Berry's journalist character's Volkswagon Bug get run off of a bridge and into a body of water.  There are moments of laugh out loud humor.  This movie was never boring; the three hours flew by, and indeed I started it over again a few hours after finishing it the first time.  The plot is pretty much what you have read but here's the thing:  THIS FILM IS NOT PRETENTIOUS. It is a simple story.  Seriously.  It's not difficult to get your head 'round what;s going on.  That fact alone is a testament to the Wachowski's skill.  There are good guys and bad guys.  Sometimes the good guys win and sometimes they lose.  There is an overarching story the concludes satisfactorily.  There are sci-fi shootouts and bar room punchups.  What I mean to say is the directors have made a crowd-pleasing popcorn movie, not some 'difficult' art house curio.  I am glad they made this movie because I enjoyed watching it very much and I can't wait to watch it again.  And again.
summary: Halle Berry is a very old man.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: waste of money and 3 hours!!!!  all over the place and in 2 of the time frames featured, we could not understand a damn thing they said
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Turn on the closed captioning or else you will miss half of what's being said. But even then it's hard to figure out who is who in the different time periods. it was semi entertaining, but I wouldn't recommend it. The over all moral of the story was a bit cliche to base the entire movie off of.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: "Cloud Atlas" is an epic-scale movie that almost runs three hours. And it is not just a long movie. It is a tapestry of six tales woven together, six tales set in six different eras. Each story employs cinematic genre conventions: comedy, historical drama, sci-fi thriller, post-apocalyptic action, etc.Actors including Tom Hanks, Halle Berry, Jim Broadbent and Hugh Grant play different roles in each story arc. All threads are thematically connected to each other in various ways. A certain phrase or action recurs throughout the "main" storyline. This is an ambitious project, something like modern-day version of D.W. Griffith's "Intolerance." And like "Intolerance," "Cloud Atlas" failed at the box office.So is the film so bad? I found some narrative threads are weak, but at least I wasn't bored. The film itself is not hard to follow. The skillful editing that connects six narratives seamlessly is just wonderful. As to the film's content, while some viewers find "Cloud Atlas" thought-provoking, others will find it rather shallow and pretentious. I happened to fall in the latter group, though I admit the way the film keeps telling its stories like Scheherazade is fascinating."Cloud Atlas" is directed by Andy and Lana Wachowski of "Matrix" fame, and Tom Tykwer, best known for "Run Lola Run." If you have seen these two films, where style takes precedence over substance, you know what you are in for. Whether the intricate narrative of "Cloud Atlas" is a groundbreaking achievement or a once only gimmick remains to be seen. I for one enjoyed watching the film, but I would rather watch only the Sonmi arc featuring terrific Doona Bae again in a conventional narrative.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I think the biggest sin of this movie is that it makes the audience pay attention and think instead of just sit back and be entertained.  As such some found this way too confusing.  I did too for the first 15 minutes or so, but then I started to see it weave together like a tapestry and it got more and more interesting because it really didn't have to fit together on all levels to work on all levels.  The movie was a bit long, but it basically needed to be for all it undertook.  I can't imagine how long the editing process must have been.As for the cinimematography....All I can say is WOW!  One of the most visually beautiful film I've eveeer seen...and I've only seen it on my own TV.  I bet the big screen at the theatre was really stunning.If you don't like to think much wwhile being entertained then you'll most likely find this confusing and/or boring.  If you like movies that keeps you on your toes and offers different perspectives than what you're used to....You're going to love this movie
summary: Damn Good, But Does Require Thinking
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: One of the best reflections as one character was going to be executed....when one life closes and another door opens....and life/soul moves on.....the essence of the movie and is well presented....and the reason why such stories intertwine....a very highly recommended movie to be seen several times over.
summary: Life moves from generation to generations
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I got the bluray via Netflix and thought the graphics were excellent. I haven't read the book so this didn't make as much sense to me as it did for those that had. I am not sure I understand the purpose of telling six stories at a time. Maybe this is for audiences with ADD and those that "think" they are deep thinkers.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The movie was too slow ant I had a hard time keeping up with the characters over the many time zones. I am glad I saw it on Amazon and not in the movies.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: When I started watching it, I didn't think I would like it. but it kept getting better and when it was finished I was glad I rented it.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Only the Warchowskis could have approached such a monumental and transcendent book and made a masterpiece from a masterpiece! Although the film begins with a fractured and diffuse series of flashbacks and flash forwards, it is fascinating from the start. For the first hour, I was thinking, "This movie is totally whack!". Still, I could not look away. Each scene is enrapturing, disturbing, beautiful, emotional or all things at once.  By mid-film I could see the seemingly disparate elements of the story lines from each characters' lifetimes begin to merge into a story of good and evil, rupture and revolution, greed and kindness and above all, love.The cast is as expansive and impeccable as is the film itself...and oh, the music, the cinematography, the make-up, the special effects! Oscar worthy performances abound. Of particular note are Tom Hanks, Susan Sarandon, Hugh Grant, Jim Broadbent, Bae Doona and Hugo Weaving. Written, directed and produced by Lana and Andy Warchowski and adapted from the novel by David Mitchell, Cloud Atlas tops my A-list for the year! Anyone who loved the Matrix the first time they saw it, is in for a delightful surprise.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This movie was different from what I expected; I was somewhat disappointed, but the casting was excellent, the performances of high quality, and the special effects amazing.  Overall, it was much darker and gloomier than I expected from the reviews and previews.
summary: Excellent casting, Choppy storyline that is difficult to follow
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This is one of those movies where reading the book prior to seeing the film might be advantageous. There are a lot of ideas discussed in this film and the book definitely gave me a head start on them. Cloud Atlas tells the stories of two couples, reincarnated through the ages, and how karma impacts everyone. The movie is told differently than the book, staggering the stories, but this works better for Hollywood; it was easier to maintain continuation of all the timelines.The make up and costumes were fantastic. Each actor wore between five and seven different looks!Someone mentioned using subtitles in certain parts: do. It'll be easier than having to rewind, or thinking that you got the idea, but...Don't go into this movie thinking it's a simple watch. You'll have to follow, and think. You'll have to put two and two together and figure out what you end up with. But in the end you'll find it was a wonderful journey!
summary: Reading the book might be a good idea
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I'm a Tom Hanks fan, and maybe I just didn't, as the storyteller requested, give it enough time, but I just got tired of bouncing through such disjointed scenes and trying to keep up with the story. Also, just a little too much yukky stuff for my enjoyment.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cloud Atlas is not for everyone. Its use of multiple stories in different time periods to make a sociological statement is obviously in the experimental stage. This concept is not completely new, Shakespeare invented the concept of telling one story that could be understood by all people's from different sociological backgrounds and Shakespeare is considered by many to be the greatest literary writer of all time. Like Blade Runner and The Fifth Element, this film tries to break ground in movie making. Only time will tell if it gets better with age or simply becomes a cult classic.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This film is visually stunning and has some great acting from everyone. I just wish I had read the book or had access to a manual when watching it, because that might have helped with comprehending the plotlines, which take place in different centuries and featuring the same actor in multiple roles.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This has to be the best movie I have ever seen!  It will leave you spellbound and in awe. Great storyline matched with beautiful cinematography. I waited a long time to see this film. It was a long film but if you were attentive, it went fast in time. I truly enjoyed it immensely.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This is a very difficult movie to watch. It's three hours of your brain trying to figure out the connection between all of the different time periods. Maybe it wouldn't have been so bad if it had been a shorter movie, but not being able to understand what's going on for almost three hours was not enjoyable.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Considering some of the movies that are popular in the cinema these days -- from dumb, car-related flicks like the "Fast & Furious 6", "G.I. Joe", "Identity Thief", or the latest Tyler Perry dreck -- it's no surprise that most American movie goers aren't imaginative, well-read, or, let's face it, bright enough to understand or figure the relatively simple, but true, message behind "Cloud Atlas".And expecting them to be able to figure out that Tom Hanks, as Zachary, is speaking in the sort of broken English that would be prevalent after an Apocalyptic event due to set backs in civilization -- heck, it's even prevalent in parts of society today -- or to have the maturity to sit and figure out the disparate plot threads as the movie progresses is likely expecting too much of a society that has everything spoon-fed to it (via TV and the internet).But for THOSE VIEWERS INTELLIGENT AND MATURE ENOUGH (always remembering intelligence and maturity don't automatically come with age), "Cloud Atlas" is a visual cornucopia and a heartfelt message of hope.The various stories run the gamut of "genres", from an Historical sea-faring adventure set in the 1800s, to a romance between two men (one of them a bisexual musical composer) during the 1930s, to a mystery during the 1970s, to a comical misadventure amongst old folks in 2012, to a science fiction thriller in the mid 21st century to a dystopian, science fiction/fantasy parable in a time after an unnamed, apocalyptic event (the time in which Zachary lives).  All of it "framed" by an aged, "story-telling" Zachary as he recounts his life, and the lives of others, to a group of young children.Other reviewers have already encapsulated the various plot elements (check out the five star reviews, you'll find plenty), so I'll just say that the writer/directors and the actors have all done a great job of bringing together six disparate stories and making them one whole vision of world peopled by THOSE WHO TRY TO HELP ONE ANOTHER and THOSE WHO ONLY PREY ON OTHERS.A five-star film-viewing experience, for sure.
summary: A Fast-Paced, Epic That Blends SF with Romance and Mystery
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: You really have to pay attention to keep up with all the different story lines.There is a beautiful theme that runs through all the stories.I was drawn to it because of the complexity and the idea of a small group of great actors that swap roles through time in vastly different but connected stories.  I was under the impression that the characters in each story carried over from previous incarnations in new bodies, but I lost that in many cases.  Perhaps some of the clips that were cut would have helped with this continuity.  Overall I liked the movie, even if it disappointed in some small details.  The grand vistas and the overall story are beautiful and it is well worth watching on the largest screen you have available.
summary: Lots of stuff going on here
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This was a very ambitious movie, weaving together scenes over a wide span of time. It was interesting to see the same actors in many different roles. I know that this movie had a difficult time being made, because it's not the typical Hollywood fare. Well worth seeing.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: Most films you get on the first viewing. This may not be one of them."Cloud Atlas" may not be your type of film but if it is and it intrigues you enough, you'll find yourself drawn back to watch it more than once because of the nonlinear storytelling which thematically links six different periods of time from the past, present to the future. The theme driving the film is that our lives have a ripple effect through time and that our souls continue to reappear with a chance of absolution for past mistakes. In some cases the characters (those played by Hugo Weaving and Hugh Grant for example) continually get it wrong and grow worse with each incarnation.As others have pointed out "Cloud Atlas" is much likeThe Fountain [HD] except that the editing of the film links each era based on actions, events and what happens to the characters in each given year. The stories take place in the following times/places: 1849 in the South Pacific as a lawyer tries to broker a slave deal; England and Scotland in 1936 as a gay composer struggles to complete his own masterpiece; San Francisco, CA 1978 focusing ona reporter trying to break a story about a dangerous power plant who's life is in danger; England in 2012 as a publisher gets an unexpected windfall when his author (a former thug)kills a critic; the year 2144 in Neo Seoul (Korea) as a "Fabricant" (an artifically engineer person) is interviewed about leading a revolution prior to her execution; the big island in an undisclosed far future where Earth has fallen into two camps--one advanced and the other primative struggling to survive on what's left of our world.The Blu-ray is a very nice transfer of the film. Each period has a unique look to it in terms of the photography and color scheme. We also get a lossless 5.1 audio mix as well as Spanish and French tracks. There are also subtitles in all English, Spanish and French.The description by Amazon is incorrect. The film DOES include special features. There isn't a commentary track (which is sad but understandable given that Lana and Andy Wachowskis don't care for doing them) however both appear with co-director/co-writer Tom TykwerPerfume: The Story of a Murderer [HD] andRun Lola Run [Blu-ray] ) in a series of featurettes that include David Mitchell the author of the original novel.The featurettes:"A Film Like No Other" (7:15), "Everything Is Connected" (8:00),"Impossible Adaptation" (9:07),"The Essence of Acting" (7:20),"Spaceships, Slaves and Sextets","The Bold Science Fiction of Cloud Atlas" (7:14) and "Eternal Recurrence" (7:39)each focusing on a different aspect of the production from the adaptation of Mitchell's novel to the challenge of playing the mulitple characters and how the actors connected with them.The menu is static and, aside from the image from the cover of the box, surprisingly generic.For those willing to give the film a chance and not looking for a more conventional bit of entertainment "Cloud Atlas" is worth it. For others, it will be a journey that is as pointless as the characters Hugh Grant and Hugo Weaving play in the film.Not everyone will like the film and it takes getting used to a narrative not told in a conventional sense but for those up to the challenge "Cloud Atlas" is a rewarding (if flawed) film that tries to do things a bit differently.
summary: Blu-ray review: Challenging nonlinear story told in six different time periods (past-future) with the same "souls" in each story
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This is a movie I want to own.  Very interesting and beautifully done.  Cloud Atlas is definitely a movie I could watch many times without getting tired of it.  All of the actors involved did a first-rate job.  Amazing work.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: With the multiple stories to follow, the producers/directors make the transitions between stories too choppy.  Also, the dialog in one story is very hard to hear/understand.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The book was moderately entertaining if not a little confused in some of its story telling.  The movie helps to explain some parts of the novel that were murky.  This is particularly true of the final story of the Islander.  In the book, the author uses the same annoying pidgin language to narrate the tale.  It gave me a head ache.  In the film, there should have been subtitles to to along with the new speak but there is enough action that the continuity is not too badly maimed.  I did enjoy the use of the cast in multiple roles.  My favorite story in the book was the escaping oldsters.  This actually worked for me in the film.  Had I not read the book I would have had a lot of what the hell just happened moments since the film script slices and dices all four story lines to death.  Really, read the book then see the movie for the sake of your sanity.
summary: Helps explain parts of the book
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: For a film named for a piece of music within the story it tells, the soundtrack is uniformly uninspired. Various genre stories are interwoven, without any of them transcending the limitations of other films their styles are borrowed from. While some of the secondary actors are good, the stars given secondary performances. Nothing wrong with it as a B movie, except it tries so lamely to be more.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: All I can say is this movie has kept me thinking about it for 3 days now. At first I was confused but as time went on (it is a long movie)I began to see the different meanings. Then the next day I went back and used my roku to hit various scenes throughout the film because Ifelt myself being called to take a second look. I didn't of course have enough time to sit and watch again and I used the roku remote tohit through various scenes. It helped and I saw things that I had missed the night before as well as came away with a new understandingwhich has made me want to run out and get the book.This is a moving and touching film and it matters. It's a film for thinkers as well as doers. I think it's an underrated movie and is deservingof an award for the major and I mean colossal effort it took to translate this film from a book onto the big screen while keeping the flow ofsuch a film from becoming a visual and metaphorical nightmare. It's anything but that. All I can say is, WOW!
summary: At first major confusion and then....A-HA!!
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Good acting, very good make up but the story line was hard to follow.  Having the movie on Blu-ray helped because you could go back and review scenes.
summary: intricate story line but difficult to follow
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Had to watch this a second time.  This is a film like no other.  It is six seemingly unrelated stories told in a seemingly random order and encompassing the distant past through to the distant future.  Directed by the Wachowskis and Tom Tykwer this is an incredible journey.  The cast is all top drawer talent with each actor playing six entirely different roles.  Do not be distracted by the non-linear story line(s), stick with it and you will have a cinematic experience like you have never had before!
summary: This is more than just a movie
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: The acting saves this interesting concept of someones theory of life.  It is refeshingly different or a change of pace which kept me interested but it was noy a masterpiece of epic story telling. Hanks and Berry kept it interesting enough to finish.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: When any film or book reveals its heart it always splits opinion in two. Those against its heart will attack anything to detract from its reason for being. And those who love it will support any aspect in order not to be openly perceived as...The ultimate in a non-linear narrative. Different stories from different times each cut-up and overlapping. At certain points the dialogue converges as the seeds of truth begin to grow. Spectacular ideas vie with mesmerizing visuals. Only good versus bad seems to endure.And the politics of today are exploded. The greed of those who believe that their order is the natural order. You only hear that word 'natural' when people are being smashed. Groups are being formed. Money not people drives their lives.Cloud Atlas is for the human in us all. Not the moral delinquency of power. The beauty in each of us. None alone.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This movie is a great work. It has such depth and so many facets. We are not our own, we are all connected through time and space. Every sin and every kindness affects the present and the future. Love lifts us up and allows us to transcend. The cinematography and script are great. You may not see how all the stories are connected at first, but watch it through to the end. I love this film! :)
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Well, this was a waste of money and time.  The acting?  Excellent.  The settings?  Superb and beautiful.  The effects and make-up?  Really cool and really well-done.The story?  Like a demon-possessed professor of philosophy and religion rambling in a darkened room!  Scenes from differing storylines are cut and pasted beside each other with no coherence.  You forget who everyone is and why you should even care to remember.  Interesting relationships and ideas are cobbled together into a mish-mash of lunacy I have no patience to stitch together myself.They are all connected by karma, reincarnation, etc. but who the heck cares if I have to WORK at figuring out the storylines!?!  This movie is failure, in my opinion.  It requires way too much patience, time, backtracking, and the use of subtitles to even hear some of the dialogue!  Yes, the invented future speak is a cool idea, but subtitle it or do not cobble scenes from different eras and make believe eras together in such a confusing way!Ugghh.  This film was a frustrating mess.  It had so much potential.  Don't believe anyone who tells you it is so entertaining that they have to rewatch it again and again!  They are rewatching it because the movie is too hard to understand otherwise!AVOID at all costs.  At least someone can save money.  I didn't, but I wish--most of all- that I had my time and brainpower back!  lol.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: This was quite confusing. Perhaps better to have read the book as it moves too quickly from scene and timeline.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Rip off of the fountain with Hugh Hackman and the matrix. Except the special effects and makeup are b-movie class. 3 stars cuz I like stories like this.
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: I am not a big fan of sci-fi movies and The Wachowskis.Matrix was only a mashup of their commercial gimmicks learned.After buying this blu ray, I continued to push the day to watch, anxious that I would be disappointed.Well, I was wrong.  It is one of the specatcular movies I have ever seen.  Ok it is confusing but the entertainement value is so good that you just overlook its shortcomings.The make-up staff have done a fantastic job of disguising characters that for once, it is very very convincing.This is one of the films that I would never put up on Ebay
summary: SPECTACULAR !  merits an Oscar for editing & makeup
Title: Cloud Atlas

reviewText: Cloud Atlas is a truly unique, entertaining, and inspirational odyssey of the soul. It tells 6 different stories in six different genres that span 6 different times with each story involving how a few different archetypes (or if you wish souls) interact with each.Although it may be tempting, do not watch this movie in the hopes of patching together a common timeline or reincarnation cycle. Each story is referenced in the next chronological story  and it is hinted that some of the stories within stories may be fictional. This is an interesting take, on the effect of writing across time.All of what I have mentioned is also in the book and this movie is a competent re-telling of the book. The stories in the movie are intertwined while in the book each story is told in two halfs one in the first half of the book and one in the second half. I think this is a wise decision to help make the movie flow fluidly. The movie does a good job of helping you keep track of each story and the way it cuts the stories together help you see their similarities. Each of the sub stories could be a solid entry in the genre of film that it represents. To be able to combine these genres is an amazing feet.I have now seen Cloud Atlas 6 times and the movie inspired me to read the book. And each time I watch it I see more. Cloud Atlas gives you a lot to see, think about, and feel.
summary: Cloud Atlas is a truly unique, entertaining, and inspirational odyssey of the soul
Title: Cloud Atlas
